title: Battling Bots: How We’re Keeping LJTalks Safe Without Blocking Legit Members
author: ljtalks
content:
In the world of web development, there’s one thing we all dread—bots. As I’ve been building and refining my website, I’ve been doing my best to make sure it’s a great space for legitimate users to interact, subscribe, and join my community. But over the past few days, I’ve faced an unexpected (but interesting!) challenge: keeping bots at bay.

How Did the Bots Get In?

It all started when I noticed some suspicious registrations. While I was doing my regular tests, I began seeing odd accounts—users who signed up but had names that looked more like random characters than actual people. No email verification, no logins, and yet they kept coming!

This is a common problem across the web: bots make up around 42.3% of internet traffic, with malicious bots accounting for 27.7%, according to Imperva’s 2023 Bad Bot Report. Of course, bots registering for your site isn’t just annoying. They’re potentially harmful, slowing down your server or even paving the way for spammy content. So, I knew I needed to take action—but how do you fight back against the bots without pushing away legitimate users?

Step 1: Honeypots and reCAPTCHA

The first step I took was adding honeypots to both the contact form and the registration form. Honeypots are hidden fields that only bots (and not real users) will fill out. If a bot tries to fill out the hidden fields, I catch it and silently deny the registration.

Next up was reCAPTCHA. I experimented with versions that weren’t too intrusive for users but still effective at blocking bot submissions. With this combination in place, things started improving. Now, the honeypot system catches over 90% of bots attempting to register, while legitimate users aren’t even aware that extra measures are in place.

Step 2: Rate Limiting

Once the honeypots and reCAPTCHA were up and running, I introduced rate limiting to the user registration form. Rate limiting allows us to restrict how many requests any user or IP address can make within a short period of time. If a bot tries to hit the signup form with multiple requests per second (or even per minute), they get blocked automatically.

This was a major step forward. By blocking suspicious activity early on, we cut down bot-generated spam by nearly 80%.

Step 3: Tracking Sources and IPs

One of the more interesting steps I’ve taken is tracking where users are coming from. For every registration attempt, I now capture the referrer URL (where the user came from) and the IP address. If a new user is legitimate, great! If not, I can check the source and see if there’s a pattern to where these bots are coming from.

This simple tracking gave me more visibility into what’s happening behind the scenes. Bots from suspicious referrers and IP addresses are now quickly identified and blocked, further improving the site’s security.

The Balance: Keeping Legit Users Happy

Of course, all these defenses have to come with a balance. I don’t want to annoy legitimate users with endless captchas or have them blocked because of rate-limiting. So, I’ve made sure to fine-tune everything to be as user-friendly as possible.

That’s where the rate-limiting comes in handy—it’s set high enough that regular users shouldn’t ever feel it, but bots trying to hit the site hard get caught. Similarly, honeypots work behind the scenes, so real users won’t even know they exist.

Lessons Learned

At first, dealing with bots was annoying—just another distraction from getting the fun parts of the site up and running. But as I dove deeper, it became a really interesting challenge! It’s not just about stopping bad actors but about finding the right balance between security and usability.

Here are a few takeaways:

  1. Always track user activity: Knowing where sign-ups are coming from (referrer and IP) gives you visibility into who might be legitimate and who’s a potential bot.
  2. Layer your defenses: Combining reCAPTCHA, honeypots, and rate-limiting gives you multiple lines of protection.
  3. Keep user experience in mind: Your real users should never feel like they’re jumping through hoops to sign up. Everything needs to work seamlessly for them, while still keeping the bots out.

And that’s the story of how I’m keeping LJTalks safe while welcoming legit members. If you’re building your own project and finding yourself in a similar spot—don’t worry. There are plenty of tools to fight back against bots, and once you understand the tricks, it can even be kind of fun!

Tracking: Why It’s About Security, Not Spying

Let’s talk about tracking. It’s a word that tends to raise eyebrows, and I completely get it. In today’s world, privacy concerns are everywhere. Many of us are suspicious when we hear that websites are “tracking” something about us, and that’s completely understandable. But I want to be clear about what we’re doing and why we’re doing it.

For LJTalks, tracking user activity—like capturing the referrer URL and IP address when someone registers—has one main goal: security. It’s all about making sure that the people joining the community are real, legitimate users, not bots or bad actors trying to mess with the site.

Why Do We Track Referrers and IPs?

When someone signs up, I capture:

  • Referrer URL: This tells me where the person came from—whether it’s a social media post, a Google search, or another website. If I see suspicious patterns, like users coming from odd or untrustworthy sources, it gives me a clue that they might be bots.
  • IP Address: This is another useful piece of information. Bots often use fake or unusual IP addresses, so tracking IPs helps me catch them before they can cause trouble.

That’s it. I’m not interested in where you go after you leave the site or anything invasive like that. I only track what’s necessary to keep the site safe and make sure that real people—people like you—are protected.

What Does This Mean for Legitimate Users?

For legitimate users, this tracking actually improves your experience. By keeping bots and spam out, I can focus on creating a community that’s safe, welcoming, and free from the annoyances that often plague other sites. It helps keep things running smoothly, ensuring the website remains responsive and functional for everyone who wants to join and interact.

It’s a balancing act, though. I’m committed to doing the bare minimum necessary to ensure the site’s security and to protect your privacy. I don’t want to track more than I need to—just enough to keep the bad actors away and the good ones engaged.

Why You Shouldn't Worry

When people think of “tracking,” they often picture invasive surveillance or companies selling their data to advertisers. But that's not the kind of tracking I’m talking about here. My focus is solely on protecting your experience and making the site better for everyone.

Here’s what I’m not doing:

  • I’m not selling your data.
  • I’m not tracking your browsing habits outside of LJTalks.
  • I’m not storing unnecessary personal details about you.

Instead, I’m using this information to identify unusual behavior—like bots registering in bulk—and prevent those patterns from disrupting the experience for legitimate users.

Transparency and Your Trust

At the end of the day, I want you to know that your trust is my priority. I’m being upfront about what I’m doing because I believe that’s the right thing to do. If you ever have concerns or questions about how I handle security and privacy, I’m always open to discussing it. My tracking efforts are entirely in service of creating a better, safer community for real people, and nothing more.

Facing Similar Issues?

title: Day 3 of My Coding Journey: Tackling HTML Essentials and Discovering Agile
author: ljtalks
alt_text: Photo by https://unsplash.com/@Shallow focus photography of white ceramic mug near laptop by ale s bianchi
content:
Today’s focus was more HTML essentials; I am an absolute beginner, remember?


On the list: tables, forms, and form descriptions.


Having found the last (first) two days a breeze, today Brain was just not Braining. I found myself too easily distracted. Every pop-up (that I've forgotten how to disable) promised too much excitement, and that elusive dopamine hit that never really pays off. Anyway, head down, more coffee, get stuff done.


The highlight of the day was our first collective group tutorial. Subject: Agile.


What?


Don't forget I've literally had "out of office" on for nearly 20 years.


We focused on a shared app/workspace, described to me as a virtual whiteboard/group planner/brainstorming tool—a place to plan and collaborate. Completely alien to me. Note to Brain: "Try harder"!


So, I embraced it! I got some virtual "post-it notes" stuck in various online spaces and started to get the hang of it. I’m still not entirely sure what Agile is all about, but that’s okay. I’m sure I’ll appreciate it more as we go along.


The best part? I survived another day! Finished up the day's essential tasks before the kids got home from school, and even started on tomorrow's schedule. Brain seems to be in top gear now (Night owl?), and I’ve almost completed tomorrow’s timetable. 🤣


Feeling accomplished, also not counting my chickens yet, but ready for Day 4! 🚀


As I continue this journey, I'm excited about the potential to help others progress from where I am right now to where I might be when you find me. I've got my core staples in the background which I still love; social media management and video editing projects ongoing—creating a great balance of creativity and learning.

title: Morning Thoughts: Gratitude, Websites, and the Affiliate Journey
author: ljtalks
content:
When I wake up in the morning, before I even get out of bed, I like to lie still for a few moments and try to be grateful, even though my brain is usually spinning with all the things I have to do. Right now, it's intense. Here I am, building my own website from scratch. Sure, I couldn’t do it without Django, Python, and a little bit of JavaScript here and there, but it's mine.


And I have to give credit where it’s due—ChatGPT has been an unexpected companion in all of this. I’d be feeling really isolated and overwhelmed without it. He's like that friend who's always there to help, even if sometimes he gets a little too confident (seriously, who knew there were so many types of reCAPTCHA?). You know that friend who’s all, "Yeah, we got this!" and then you end up in some tricky situations? Yeah, that’s ChatGPT. But he's gotten me out of plenty of jams, too.


So this morning, I was thinking about how to monetize the site. In the last 18 months, I’ve picked up so many new tools and software packages—some have been great, some... meh. And the thing is, almost all of them offer affiliate programs. For those who don’t know, affiliate marketing means that if I tell you how much I love a product and you decide to try it out, I get compensated for recommending it. It’s not new. Affiliate programs have been around almost as long as the internet. Before that, it was in magazines, TV shows, all sorts of places.


Some people don't love affiliate links, and I get it. But if you're okay with ads on YouTube or TV, it's not all that different. Except here, the content is relevant to what you're already interested in—and, bonus, you might actually find something valuable!


Why Custom Websites?

Aside from affiliate marketing, I’m also hoping people will realize how useful a custom-built website can be. Sure, there are plenty of services out there to help you run a business, but what if you don’t want 50 tabs open at any given moment? What if you want something that does exactly what you need it to do? That’s who I’m hoping to reach.


I’m not trying to build the next Skool (or insert other big website here) - I’m more curious to see if I can. There are so many quirky little things you learn along the way, like handling bots and reCAPTCHA, things I wouldn’t have even thought about before. But it’s all part of the process, and honestly, it's kind of fun in a weird way.

Yesterday, I was listening to an interview with one of the co-founders of Ghost, the open-source blogging platform. It’s non-profit, built to rival the likes of WordPress, and it’s really impressive. If I wasn’t building my own blog, Ghost would definitely be my next stop.

The Subscription Economy

These days, everyone is chasing subscriptions. You build a product once, and people will pay for it over and over again. It’s not a new concept - music and movies have worked this way forever. No one complains about musicians getting royalties (well... maybe a little), but people deserve to be compensated for their work.

I don’t know if this website will make me much money. Maybe a little from affiliate marketing, but that’s not the point. Yes, I need to make money - none of us can live off fresh air, and I’ve got three teenagers with never-ending appetites. But this project is also about seeing if I can do it. Can I build the site I want, without cutting corners? Because if I can do it for myself, then I can do it for others too. And there's something really satisfying about seeing it all come together exactly the way I envisioned.

The Battle with Bots

Today, I’ll continue the battle with reCAPTCHA. It's not something I thought I’d care about much. Those annoying little “Are you human?” things can feel dumb at times. But when your half-finished site gets 30 new “subscribers” overnight with names like "hgflXUIY" or "kjhgaui," plus a spammy casino ad in your inbox... well, you start to take that stuff a bit more seriously.

title: "Wait, How Did You Find Me?!" – A New Developer's Spin Into the Spotlight

content:

Then BAM! Out of nowhere, people start finding my site. Actual people. Clicking on things. Signing up for stuff. Even sending me spammy casino ads through my contact form! 😳

I mean, what?! Who are you? How did you find me? I wasn’t ready for this! Spoiler alert: This is a developer’s worst nightmare, when your site’s still in its “please don’t look at me” phase.

“Let’s Keep Calm...” I Told Myself

No big deal, right? I’ve built this email signup system, everything is under control... sort of. But now, there are actual users in my database, and I’m suddenly faced with real-world questions like, “Why is the welcome email not exactly... welcoming?”

“Where Did the Spammers Come From?!” 

And let's not forget the lovely person who sent me an email asking me to “Join Some Casino.” Thanks for that. Really added to the zen-like experience of trying to figure out how people even found my website! Spammers move fast, folks. I think they may have even found me before I found myself.

"The Site is... Mostly Functional!"

To all the friendly (and not-so-friendly) visitors who are suddenly here: Surprise! The site’s not quite ready yet. But hey, I’m working on it. The email signup form should be working, though if you get a weird error message, consider it my quirky way of saying, “We’re still ironing things out.”

But that’s life as a developer, right? One minute you’re knee-deep in code, and the next you’re elbows-deep in plumbing. This is the glamorous tech life I signed up for. 😅

Testing in Progress...

So, if you see things behaving a little... strange, please bear with me. The site’s still under construction. If you’re trying to sign up for emails or log in and it’s not quite working, don’t worry. It will be—soon! You’re just catching me at a bit of a wild moment.


But if you do manage to sign up and receive a strange email... Congrats! You’ve just witnessed live, real-time testing. I’ll have it fixed shortly, promise!

Wait, How Did You Find Me?!

Seriously though... how did you all find me? I’m not even promoting the site yet. But hey, welcome! Enjoy the chaos. Just know, it’s a work in progress—and so am I! 😉

title: So, You Think Building Your Own Email List Is a Good Idea?
author: ljtalks
content:
Picture this: You’re sipping your coffee, full of confidence, keyboard at the ready. You’re staring at your screen, thinking, “Why use a plugin or service like Kit (formerly ConvertKit) when I can just build my own custom email list system? How hard could it be?”

Spoiler alert: Two. Days. Later.

It turns out, building an email system is kind of like chasing your own tail. You can’t stop, you can’t win (at least not without several rounds of coffee), but you’re pretty sure you’re getting somewhere. Maybe.

The Unfolding Saga

It started off as an innocent idea: "I’ll just add a form, sprinkle in some checkboxes, do some backend validation, and voilà—custom email system!" What followed was a lesson in both humility and patience, as well as a deep dive into the wonderful world of modals, checkboxes, and the mysterious art of CSRF tokens.

The Checkbox Chronicles

There’s something oddly satisfying about a checkbox... until you realize that unchecked boxes might as well be unchecked emotions. Are users unsubscribing, or are they just confused? The real kicker was getting everything to work in tandem without causing the form to break down in tears—like I almost did.

Modal Madness

Let’s talk modals. These little pop-up windows of joy are there to make sure users are really, *really* sure they want to unsubscribe. But after testing my modal 30 times (not that I’m counting), it started to feel like an endless loop of uncertainty. Click unsubscribe, reload the page, nothing happens. Did it work? Maybe the modal is stuck in existential limbo... along with my sanity.

The Double Opt-In Dilemma

Double opt-in - good for users, bad for developers who enjoy their weekends. Do I send a confirmation when they subscribe? What about when they unsubscribe? Oh wait, they changed their mind. Quick, send them three more emails to make sure we’re all on the same page.

Validation, Schmalidation

I’d like to think I’m a validation pro. After all, how hard can it be to stop someone from subscribing without an email? Well, let’s just say there were moments when my form either let users subscribe without entering their email (oops) or didn’t let them do anything at all. Validation is apparently a delicate art that can teeter on the edge of madness.

Lessons Learned (Or Maybe Not)

In hindsight, I could have saved myself two days (and several cups of coffee) by using a pre-built solution like Kit. In fact, Kit (formerly ConvertKit) is an excellent choice, highly recommended by many people I know and trust. With Kit, you could have your email list up and running faster than I can finish my first cup of coffee - and that’s saying something.

But where’s the fun in that?

The “I Think It’s Working” Phase

Is my system working? Yes. Will I keep refreshing the page just to make sure it’s still working? Definitely. But the important thing is, I won. I created a completely custom email system that no one else will ever have. Not because it’s revolutionary... but because no one else would want it.

Could I Have Used Kit?

Yes, and honestly, I might recommend it to you if you’re just getting started. Kit has all the tools you need to manage newsletters, autoresponders, and email campaigns, without writing a single line of code. While I’ve been deep in checkbox purgatory, you could be sipping your coffee with your email list running smoothly in the background.

In Conclusion: The Winner’s Circle

So, did I lose my mind? Almost. But I came out the other side with a quirky, one-of-a-kind email system that only I could create. Would I do it again? Probably... but maybe next time I’ll think about Kit first. After all, I might enjoy having an extra day to actually do something other than wrestling with checkboxes.

So, whether you’re looking for a plug-and-play solution like Kit or want something custom (and maybe a little crazy), there’s a path for everyone. Just remember: coffee is mandatory, patience is recommended, and if you get stuck... maybe just ask Kit to do the hard work for you.

title: How to Not Lose Your Mind (But Almost) While Building Your Own Project
author: ljtalks
content:
So, you think you’re ready to build your very own Django web app? Ready to ride the sweet wave of self-satisfaction as your code glows with the pristine clarity of a thousand suns? Well, strap in, because you’re about to enter The Coding Twilight Zone.

Step 1: Install Everything You’ve Heard Of. Then, Realize You Installed More Than You Needed.

All right, so first things first, install Django. Great! You’re doing fine. Wait, what’s this? Allauth? Blocktrans? What in the world is blocktrans?! Does it sound helpful? Sure! Do I know what it does? Nope, but why not? YOLO, right?

Fast-forward to three hours later when blocktrans has become your new coding nemesis. It’s got your signup page tied in knots, throwing errors like it’s confetti at a coding failure party. 🎉

Step 2: Uh-Oh, Circular Imports – Is This Some Sort of Evil Math?

Remember that time you tried to use your models in views, but then your views needed models, and suddenly your app went into full-on panic mode? Yeah, me too. Ever tried explaining a circular import to someone? It’s like explaining why the chicken crossed the road but with more code and a dash of “I’m not sure the chicken made it.”

Fun Fact: Every time you get a circular import, a baby coder somewhere forgets what sleep is.

Step 3: The NavBar That Just Won’t Listen

“Oh, you want a working navigation bar? That’s adorable.” – My code, probably.

So, you add a login link to your navbar. Simple, right? WRONG. Your page throws a fit and suddenly redirects people to some random abyss, all while you’re wondering what you did to deserve this. And CSS? Well, it was there, but now it’s squiffy. That’s right, squiffy.

At this point, you start questioning things like, “Who am I? Did I really choose this life? Am I in a secret reality show where they see how much coding frustration a person can take before they crack?”

Step 4: The Blocktrans Conspiracy

Imagine this: you’re happily coding away, and then you get hit with this message that you can’t blocktrans inside another block. Cue the what the heck moment. It’s like realizing you’ve been putting sugar in your coffee, and then out of nowhere, someone tells you it’s salt. WHY DOES THIS EXIST?! Does it sound like a feature? Yes. Does it sound like an annoying twist in my code? Double yes.

It turns out blocktrans snuck into my project like an uninvited party guest, courtesy of Allauth. If there’s one thing you should take away from this: beware of the blocktrans. It’s lurking.

Step 5: Should I Just Copy Someone Else's Project?

I’m not going to lie—there was a moment, late at night, with a rapidly shrinking deadline, when I thought, “Why not just… y'know... borrow someone else's project?” But here’s the thing—I’m doing this my way. Yeah, maybe I could copy-paste a “perfect” project in under 10 hours, but where’s the thrill of spiraling into coding madness with your own work? Where’s the growth if you’re not losing a few strands of hair along the way?

Step 6: Pizza. Panic. Push On.

After a coding-induced existential crisis, I took a moment for some self-care: pizza and a pep talk. What would future-me say if I gave up now? Future-me would probably still be coding because… spoilers: it never ends. But here’s the thing—I’ll be better for it. Every line of code is a lesson, even if some of those lessons sound like, “Don’t trust blocktrans.”

Step 7: Git Commit—To My Own Madness

As the submission deadline looms, and the code errors pile up like unread emails, I realize something: This is the journey. If I wanted easy, I’d have taken up knitting. But no, I chose to be a developer. And that means sometimes you wrestle with your code until it submits (pun intended) and finally works… and sometimes, you end up writing a blog post to laugh about it before diving back in.

So here we are, tired but determined, marching toward that finish line. Future me is going to look back at this and say, “Wow, what a disaster—but hey, you made it, and now you can debug in your sleep!”

title: The Whirlwind Coding Frenzy – Progress, High-Fives, and a Big Reset
author: ljtalks
content:
Ahh, the sweet taste of victory and the bitter flavour of code-induced chaos. That sums up the last 24 hours of my final project journey – a blend of brilliance, panic, and the occasional "What was I even thinking?!"

Picture this: it's late at night, coffee-fuelled energy levels are dangerously high, and I'm elbows deep in wiring up the products app to the blog. The blog. That same blog that has been responsible for countless errors, comments disappearing like socks in a washing machine, and me considering a new career in sock puppet theatre.

But last night? Oh, we were unstoppable! Everything just clicked. The products app started behaving like an actual app, and for a brief, glorious moment, it felt like the universe itself was high-fiving us. We were on fire, the code was flowing, and there was even this moment where ChatGPT suggested I go to bed. Like, "Hey, you’re human – sleep’s a thing, remember?"

Naturally, I laughed it off and carried on, but you know what? He was kinda right.

This morning, though? Yeah, I may have overslept (just a tad). Instead of hitting the code straight away, I decided to take a break, grab some coffee, and ponder life's mysteries – like, why does the universe hate perfectly written blog comments? Why? 😭

And then, back to work. First thing I did? Strip out loads of stuff from the products app. You know, the bits that were super cool and overly complicated. The stuff that works, but for the love of all things Django, I need to prove it works to my course instructor. And let’s be real, that means testing... lots of testing. But the funny thing? I still haven’t tackled the custom model with CRUD functionality. Yep, the one I need to actually submit this thing. And I’m over here unravelling the mysteries of how products relate to each other, figuring out what’s free, what requires a sign-up, and what needs a payment. It’s a bit like hosting a party and forgetting whether the snacks are on the house or cost $20 a plate.

So, here we are. It’s been a rollercoaster, filled with moments of triumph, followed by hours of "Wait, did I really remove that perfectly good code on purpose?" 😂

But hey, it’s all part of the ride. This project is like a complicated, slightly confused child that I’ve come to love. And even though it’s far from over, I can see the finish line peeking through the chaos.

Now, time to go back and tackle that CRUD model before I forget my own name.

Here’s to more late nights, high-fives, and maybe (just maybe) remembering that sleep is a thing.

title: Adding Images to Your Blog: The Good, The Bad, and The Drag-and-Drop
author: ljtalks
content:
Today, we’re tackling a burning question that’s kept many a blogger awake at night (or at least mildly confused during their morning coffee): How the heck do I add images to my blog posts?

Whether you’re demonstrating how to crochet a cat sweater 🧶🐱 or showcasing your dog’s latest modelling portfolio 📸🐶, images are essential. But getting them exactly where you want them in your blog content can feel like a game of Tetris—one wrong move, and everything’s out of place!

Let’s tackle the different ways to handle images in your blog, from “basic but functional” to “who needs code when I can just drag and drop?”

Method 1: The “One Image to Rule Them All” Approach

In this classic strategy, you have one glorious image that sits at the top of your blog post, like a proud king on its throne. It’s perfect for a nice header photo that says, “Look at me! I’m the main event!”

Use Case:

  1. Blog post about your last vacation? Throw up a scenic shot of that beach. 🏖️
  2. Writing about how to bake the perfect pie? Picture of a pie. Done. 🥧

Pros:

  1. Simplicity: No need to worry about image placement—it’s always at the top!
  2. Consistency: Your posts all have a unified look.

Cons:

  1. Limited: What if you want to show that and a close-up of the pie crust? Uh-oh.
  2. Boring: It’s like having one flavor of ice cream. Sure, it’s fine, but what about sprinkles?

Method 2: Rich Text Editors—A Little Magic for the Masses ✨🪄

Enter the saviour of formatting, the mighty Rich Text Editor! Tools like Summernote and CKEditor let you add images inside your content. It’s like having a superpower—just click, insert, and voila! Your pie crust gets the spotlight it deserves.

Use Case:

  1. Want to sprinkle in images throughout your text? Easy!
  2. Describing a complex process? Add step-by-step pictures to guide the reader.

Pros:

  1. Control: Drop images wherever you want. No, really, wherever.
  2. User-Friendly: No coding required. It’s like dragging a sticker onto a digital scrapbook.

Cons:

  1. Storage Shenanigans: Where do all these images live? Server? Cloud? Tiny gnomes? This can get tricky.
  2. Overkill for Simplicity: If you just want one picture, this might feel like using a sledgehammer to crack a nut.



Relatable Programmer Moment: Now, I'd love to tell you all how this works in practise, but here's the catch; I can't actually test it right now because I'm in the middle of debugging! 😂 Yep, that's right, I'm flying blind on this one. For all I know, Summernote could be out there in the code wilderness, adding random cat memes to every post. I'll check it out once I finally get my app back in the browser, but for now, we'll just pretend it's working perfectly. Fellow coders, you know the struggle!



Method 3: Custom Image Handling—A DIY Adventure 🛠️🔧

Feeling adventurous? Why not build your own image handling solution! This is like deciding to bake a cake and build the oven yourself. 🧑‍🍳

Use Case:

  1. Need ultimate control over your images, captions, and layouts?
  2. Want to show off your coding chops and make something truly custom?

Pros:

  1. Full Control: You’re the boss! Decide exactly how images behave and appear.
  2. Customization: Create custom layouts, galleries, or slideshows that put other blogs to shame.

Cons:

  1. Complexity: You’re not just baking the cake; you’re sourcing the flour, churning the butter, and designing the bakery’s logo.
  2. Maintenance: Bugs, updates, and “Wait, why is my cat picture showing up in every post?”

Method 4: Drag-and-Drop Platforms—The “I Got This” Solution 🖱️💪

If coding isn’t your jam, there’s always the option to use a drag-and-drop platform like WordPress, Wix, or Squarespace. It’s like ordering a pizza instead of cooking—fast, easy, and

you get what you need without breaking a sweat.

Use Case:

  1. You need to build a blog fast and don’t have time for custom code.
  2. You’re a visual person who likes to see exactly how things will look.

Pros:

  1. Visual Editing: Move things around with a click and drag.
  2. No Coding Needed: Focus on your content, not the code.

Cons:

  1. Limited Customization: Sometimes, you just can’t get that pepperoni where you want it. 🍕
  2. Dependence: You’re tied to the platform’s features and quirks.

Which One Should You Choose? 🤷‍♀️

Here’s the thing: there’s no one-size-fits-all answer. It all depends on what you need:

  1. Go for Method 1 if you want to keep things simple.
  2. Use Method 2 (Rich Text Editor) if you want to add images within your text without getting your hands dirty with code.
  3. Try Method 3 (Custom Image Handling) if you’re feeling ambitious and want to create something unique.
  4. Opt for Method 4 if you just want to get things done and focus on content, not code.

Final Thoughts 🧠

Adding images to your blog can range from “plug and play” to “rocket science,” but no matter which route you take, remember that a picture is worth a thousand words. And sometimes, a perfectly placed pie photo can say more than a thousand lines of code ever could.

So go forth, fellow bloggers, and may your images always be crisp, your captions clever, and

your content compelling. 📷✍️

Happy blogging!

title: When CSS Won't Behave: A Love-Hate Relationship with Web Design
author: ljtalks
content:
There’s a moment in every web developer’s life when they realize that CSS has a mind of its own. You write your code, preview your page, and boom—nothing looks the way it should. It’s as if your carefully constructed layout turned into a Picasso painting overnight. Welcome to the world of web design.

1. The “Why Is My Button Floating in Space?” Dilemma

You add a button. It’s supposed to sit perfectly in the middle of your form. But when you refresh the page, your button is out there… floating… like an astronaut who’s just disconnected from the spaceship. It's an existential crisis, both for you and the button. But you keep going.

2. display: none;—The Magic Trick We All Need

CSS gives us this nifty little trick to make elements disappear from the page. Want to hide that annoying header that’s messing up your design? display: none; Boom! It’s like the magician’s disappearing act. Until… you can’t figure out how to make it reappear, and now you’re Googling how to undo your own magic. Ah, the joys of CSS.

3. Flexbox—The Answer to All Your Problems (Until It Isn’t)

Flexbox! The hero we deserve and the layout saviour we need. It promises to solve all your alignment issues. You throw a flex container at your page, sit back, and wait for the magic to happen. But instead of nicely aligned boxes, your divs are playing a game of tag across the screen, and your layout looks like a puzzle where none of the pieces fit. Flexbox: saving the day one misaligned div at a time.

4. CSS Grid: Flexbox’s Big Brother

If Flexbox isn’t working, surely CSS Grid will! Right? Right?? Well, Grid steps in like an overconfident older sibling who knows exactly what’s up. You lay out your grid containers, you set your columns and rows, and then... it’s a mess. Rows are overflowing, columns are squished, and once again, you're scratching your head wondering where it all went wrong.

5. Z-Index Wars: Who Rises to the Top?

Z-index, you tricky little devil. You’ve got a few elements layered on top of each other, and suddenly, the element that should be on top is hiding underneath everything else. You set the z-index to a million, and still… it refuses to show up. It’s basically the hide-and-seek champion of your website.

6. The Final Straw: Box Shadow Shenanigans

You think, “Let’s add a little drop shadow for that wow factor.” Seems easy, right? Well, somehow, your drop shadow looks like a glowing radioactive orb around your button. Congratulations, you’ve turned your website into a scene from a sci-fi movie. This is the moment you push your chair back, sigh, and seriously contemplate a career change.

7. But Then, It Clicks

After hours of trial and error, you suddenly stumble upon the magic combination of CSS properties. The layout looks just right. The colours are perfect. The button is exactly where it should be. And for that fleeting moment, you feel like a coding god.

8. Until Tomorrow...

But of course, tomorrow you’ll open your site on another browser, and everything will be broken again. Because if there’s one universal truth about web development, it’s this: CSS giveth, and CSS taketh away.

Conclusion:
So, if you’re ever feeling lost in the tangled world of CSS, remember—you’re not alone. Somewhere out there, another coder is crying over a misaligned button. But that’s okay, because after every meltdown, comes that sweet victory of a perfectly styled page (for now). Keep going. The web needs your design skills, and so do all of us who still can't centre a div.

title: Th﻿e Epic Battle: Function-Based Views vs. Class-Based Views in Django 🥊
author: ljtalks
content:
Today, we're hurling ourselves into another coding battle royale.

Whether you’re a newbie fresh out of “Hello World” or a seasoned developer who can’t remember what day it is without a terminal prompt, you've probably come across the epic saga of Function-Based Views (FBVs) and Class-Based Views (CBVs) in Django.

What’s the Deal with Views Anyway?

In Django, views are the middlemen (or middle-persons, for inclusivity) between your database and your web page. They fetch the data you need, wrap it up neatly, and send it to your template to present to the user.

Think of them as the waitstaff of your Django restaurant, taking orders from the customer (browser), fetching the dish (data), and presenting it nicely on a plate (HTML template).

Enter the Contenders: FBVs vs. CBVs 🥇🥈

In the Left Corner: Function-Based Views (FBVs) 💪

Function-Based Views are straightforward, like your favourite coffee order at that café you’ve been going to since forever. You tell them what you want, and they get it done, no frills, no surprises.

An FBV example:

You might create a function that lists all your blog posts by fetching them from your database and displaying them in a template. It’s direct and easy to follow, perfect for someone who likes full control over each step.


Pros of FBVs:

  • Simple and Direct: You control every step. If you love having a say in every detail of your code, FBVs are for you.
  • Quick to Grasp: If you know Python, you know FBVs. It’s just a function doing exactly what you tell it to do.

Cons of FBVs:

  • Boilerplate Bonanza: As your app grows, you might feel like you're writing the same code over and over again. "Wait, didn’t I write this view yesterday?"

In the Right Corner: Class-Based Views (CBVs) 🎩

Class-Based Views are the ready-to-eat meal kits of Django. They come with everything you need: instructions, pre-measured ingredients, and the satisfaction of thinking you’re a top chef. All you need to do is follow the steps.

A CBV example:

You could use a pre-built class like ListView to handle blog post listings for you. It’s elegant, concise, and comes with built-in tools like pagination, so you don’t have to write everything from scratch.

Pros of CBVs:

  • Less Boilerplate, More Efficiency: CBVs come with built-in options for CRUD operations, form handling, and pagination. You can get your app up and running fast.
  • Built-in Features: Pagination? Check. Forms? Check. A whole arsenal of methods you can override? Absolutely. 🎉

Cons of CBVs:

  • Learning Curve: It’s like ordering sushi for the first time—there’s a lot of terminology, and you’re not quite sure which part goes where.
  • Less Direct Control: When you need custom logic that doesn’t fit neatly into a CBV’s structure, you may find yourself in a bit of a wrestling match.

So, Which Should You Choose? 🤷‍♂️

It’s like deciding between pizza and pasta for dinner—both are fantastic, and sometimes you just want both. The truth is, it depends on what you need.

Choose FBVs when you:

  • Need custom logic that doesn’t fit into a standard template.
  • Prefer a step-by-step approach where you control every aspect of your view’s logic.
  • Are working on smaller projects where writing out boilerplate code isn’t a big deal.

Choose CBVs when you:

  • Want to speed up development with built-in functionalities.
  • Are working on larger projects with repetitive patterns.
  • Appreciate the elegance of object-oriented programming (OOP) and don’t mind a little abstraction.

Real-Life Scenarios 🧩

  • FBVs: Picture building a personal blog site where you want to add custom filters or maybe throw in some random facts about cats alongside your blog posts. FBVs are your go-to because you have complete control over every query and display.

  • CBVs: Now, imagine a platform with thousands of blog posts, user comments, likes, and a complex form submission process. CBVs, with their built-in pagination and form handling, will save you heaps of time.

The Final Showdown 🥊

At the end of the day, both FBVs and CBVs get the job done. It’s not about which one is better, but about choosing the right tool for the job. FBVs give you full control over every step of your view, while CBVs offer convenience and efficiency through built-in features.

So, new coders, don’t stress over the choice. Try both, see which fits your style, and remember: whether you're hand-crafting an FBV or relying on the built-in magic of a CBV, you're still feeding the hungry monster that is your Django app.

Happy coding! 🍕🍣

title: From a Simple Blog to E-commerce Dreams: the “Scope Creep” Whirlpool…2
author: ljtalks
content:
I’m a few days deep into building my final project for the coding course; a *really* straightforward blog with some simple extra features.

Or at least, that was the plan... But then, as soon as my fingers hit the keyboard the excitement builds; Dynamic pricing! What if the first 20 items of a product were free, and the next hundred increased in price? Could I automate that? And wouldn’t it be cool if...?

Fast forward to the end of the day, staring at my screen, knowing I hadn’t hit commit for way too long, cause nothing was working, there were bits that depended on other bits that were as yet undefined, and I started to feel like I was drowning in a tangle of “cool” features with a side of “mini-meltdown”. 

I was caught in the whirlpool of “scope creep,” a new term I just learned that perfectly captures what happens when a project’s requirements expand beyond its original goals. It’s like ordering a small pizza and ending up with a three-course meal, a dessert platter, and a piano player in the corner. Fun, but overwhelming!

I had a chat with my cohort leader, who showed me some mind-blowing tricks I could integrate into my project. I don’t think he realised that I’m never short on ideas—I’m a walking brainstorm! His suggestions were incredible, and even though we talked about how he had to learn to reign his ideas in and really commit to the planning stage, and I agreed, but somehow his project inspired me to think bigger and really see how my simple site had all the hallmarks and potential of becoming an actual full-on e-commerce site, something I really didn’t envision when I started.

I’ve been pondering on a question he asked me; did I see myself as a creative person? I hesitated because I’ve never really identified as one. I’m no graphic designer, and genuinely rely on google to let me know what colours and contrasts work together. But lately, I’ve been thinking about how coding is helping me solve problems creatively. Creativity is *not* just about making things look pretty or adding fancy features; it’s more about thinking, “Can we automate that?” and finding solutions to make life easier for others, solving real world problems.

I’m starting to see that creativity and problem-solving are two sides of the same coin. Whether it’s a messy code base or a real-world issue, creativity helps us find new ways to tackle challenges. It’s about taking something that’s broken or complex and finding a way to make it work—sometimes even better than before.

You all know I’m on the rollercoaster, and I’ve had to really rein myself in, moving a lot of “cool ideas” to the “Future Features” list. (Yes, it’s a very long list!) I’m learning to balance ambition with realism, understanding that just because I can add a feature doesn’t mean I should—at least, not right now.

What’s most exciting, though, is that I’m realizing this coding journey is just the beginning. I’ve always loved helping people, and now I have a whole new skill set to do it in a different way. Whether it’s automating processes, building tools, or creating platforms, I’m finding new ways to make a positive impact.

I’m still figuring it all out, but I’m starting to see the big picture: coding is more than just a technical skill—it’s a way to turn creativity into reality and solve problems that matter. And that’s a pretty exciting place to be.

title: Git Committing to Progress When Your Brain’s Screaming “Abort Mission!”
author: ljtalks
content:
So, here’s the scene: It’s day three of my final project, and everything was on fire yesterday. We had a plan, a solid strategy, and I was feeling like a coding wizard!

Fast forward to today, and suddenly, I’m in the deep end, treading water, wondering if I even remember how to float.

And then… that sneaky little voice starts whispering: “You’ve gone too far, you’ve taken on too much. This was supposed to be simple! Are you sure you know what you’re doing? Maybe it’s time to start again...”

Cue dramatic pause.

But no! I won’t fall for it. I know this feeling. It’s the same one that pops up when you’re halfway through building IKEA furniture and realize there’s a part that looks suspiciously important lying on the floor. You’ve got the pieces, you’ve got the instructions (sort of), and you’re pretty sure it’ll all come together. Eventually.

Then it hit me: You don’t wait until the IKEA wardrobe is fully built to admire your progress, right? You take breaks after each step, maybe snap a pic to show off those slightly wobbly but upright panels, and move on. Maybe it should be the same with coding?

I’ve developed a habit of making regular commits, usually after I’ve added a small feature that works without breaking anything else. It just made sense at the time, but this project? This beast is different. “There are so many moving parts” has become my new mantra these past few days.

I don’t need perfection. I need progress.

So today, I decided to commit more frequently—even when things are only halfway working. I’ll save the “final reveal” for when everything is polished, but for now, I’m just happy to still know which way is up in the code jungle. And honestly, why didn’t I think of this sooner?

I’ll be chatting with my team later, and I’m sure their advice will be the usual: breathe, commit, grab another coffee. (Spoiler: they’re always right.)

The moral of the story? Celebrate the little wins—the buggy code, the ‘almost-working’ features—because if you wait for perfection before taking a victory lap, you might miss out on all the fun in between.

title: The Curious Case of the Cat, the ERD, and the Mysterious Many-to-One2
author: ljtalks
content:
I started today with a mission. A mission I thought I was prepared for. I had my coffee in one hand and a freshly sharpened mind in the other. It was going to be a productive day.

And then I met my nemesis... the Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD).

This wasn't just any ERD. Oh no, this was an ERD of epic proportions—like a cat sitting on your keyboard, deliberately pressing random keys and daring you to stop it. One minute I was confidently dragging lines between my User model and Blog post, and the next… those lines had minds of their own, darting across the screen like a hyperactive kitten chasing a laser pointer.

Many-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many—did I even know what these terms meant anymore? For a while, it felt like all those "ones" and "manys" were conspiring against me, like a group of cats knocking things off tables just to see what happens. And let’s not even talk about how many times I had to undo my perfectly placed boxes just because a line decided it didn’t like where it was heading! (Thanks again, imaginary cat.)

Just as I was about to throw in the towel—or possibly my laptop—things started to click. It wasn’t just about drawing lines and placing boxes, no! This was about understanding relationships. It was like trying to convince a cat that the laser pointer wasn’t out to get them. It was about realizing that a User could comment on multiple Blogs, but each Comment only had one User. It was about knowing that each Product was part of a bigger system, interacting with Purchases, Comments, and Blogs, all while your metaphorical cat knocked over yet another carefully stacked diagram box.

The lesson? Just like a stubborn cat that won't stop sitting on your keyboard, sometimes you need to let the chaos happen before the things start making sense. Eraser.io may have been my battleground today, but in the end, I tamed the wild beast (and the metaphorical cat). Once I truly understood those connections, the lines between the boxes stopped running wild and started falling into place—like a kitten finally giving up and curling into your lap.

And let's not forget the comedic moments: that time when half the lines overlapped, and I genuinely thought I’d invented a new form of abstract art, or when I learned what a "clob" was (no, not the sound you make when you drop your phone, though it should be). In this whole mess, I started wondering if my ERD diagram had secretly become a cat toy—entertaining for the cat but utterly confusing for me.

By the end of the day, what started as chaos became clarity. I now have an ERD that makes sense, and I can proudly say that the one-to-manys and many-to-ones no longer terrify me. (I can't say the same for actual cats though—those little guys are unpredictable.)

Lesson of the day: The only way to master an ERD (or a mischievous cat) is to let it be messy for a while. Let the lines run amok, let the boxes overlap—because in the end, it’s all part of the process. Eventually, everything will fall into place, and you’ll be left with a masterpiece (or at least something that looks less like abstract art and more like a diagram).

Stay tuned for tomorrow's blog post, where I’ll inevitably find myself in yet another database dilemma. Who knows, maybe next time I’ll get creative with... many-to-many relationships? 😬

Until then, my ERD and I (and the imaginary cat) are signing off, one (relationship) at a time!

title: ERD Day Drama, Plot Twists, and ‘Let’s Keep It Simple’ Realizations
author: ljtalks
content:
Well, folks, buckle up because today has been an absolute whirlwind in the land of “Let’s Build the MVP and Hope for the Best.”

First things first, I came into today ready to tackle my project planning like a boss.

I had my coffee in hand, a decent night's sleep (more or less), and a head full of ideas.

I was ready to nail down this whole project like it was no big deal.


Step 1: The ER Diagram. You know, that thing that looks all neat and tidy on paper but secretly lurks around corners waiting to smack you in the face with a “Did you really think this was gonna be easy?”


So there I am, mapping out Users and Bookings with all the confidence of a professional diagrammer (yep, I made up that word).

“Users will book services, and they’ll also buy digital products,” I thought, “Easy peasy.” Except, plot twist - in walks the realization that webinars, mentoring, PDFs, and online courses might just belong to totally different worlds.

Like, wait a minute - are webinars services or products? Do mentoring sessions need their own booking system? Should I just throw the whole thing out the window and start again?

🤔

Step 2: Panic. For a brief moment, I questioned my entire existence. But then I had an epiphany:


KEEP IT SIMPLE.


Yes, simplicity - the holy grail of getting to the MVP without losing your mind. So, after a quick chat with my tutor (who, might I add, probably heard the panic in my voice from a mile away), we agreed: we’re keeping Products for now and saving the complicated service stuff for later.


Future me can deal with that mess when I'm off the course and on my own...


Step 3: Blogging about it.

Then it hit me. This whole process of planning, scrapping ideas, re-planning, and talking myself down from the ledge is exactly the kind of thing people love to read about.

Why not blog about every twist and turn?

After all, if I’m learning at breakneck speed, surely others will find it useful.

Plus, it’ll be fun to look back on all the chaos, right?

Moral of the story: Today’s big win was realizing that less is more (at least for now), and I’m just going to focus on making things functional.

No more chasing my own tail trying to figure out if my webinars belong in the service app or the product app.

They can stay in the product app, and I’ll sleep soundly tonight knowing I haven’t created a booking system that looks like spaghetti.

So here we are, at the end of a very long day. The ER Diagram has been updated, my sanity has been restored (mostly), and I’ve learned that keeping it simple might just be the key to

success. Who knew?

Stay tuned for tomorrow’s episode of “What Could Possibly Go Wrong?” 😉

title: When Bootstrap Becomes Bootstrapocalypse A Dev’s Tale of Woe and Waffles
author: ljtalks
content:
Ah, Bootstrap. The promise of clean, responsive design and easy CSS… what could possibly go wrong? Spoiler alert: Everything. 😅

Scene 1: The Bootstrap Boogaloo

It all started with a simple idea: “Hey, let’s add Bootstrap and some basic CSS before I finish up the database. Navigation will be easier for testing!”

Fast forward to three hours later, and I’m staring at an error screen like it just insulted my family.

Who knew adding a few simple lines of Bootstrap could cause such chaos?

Links broke, styles went missing, and somewhere in the mess, I swear I saw my sanity make a break for it.

Scene 2: The Curse of the .gitignore

I made the rookie mistake of assuming Git understood I didn’t want to track staticfiles/. Oh no. It’s like inviting a vampire in—it’s all fun and games until they start sucking the life out of your project.

So there I was, undoing my previous commit, fixing my .gitignore, and desperately Googling “Why does Git hate me?”

At this point, I’d given up on fixing Bootstrap. Now it was about survival. Like, “Can I please just push this code and pretend today never happened?”

Scene 3: The Great Navigation Debacle

Adding a navigation bar for easy testing? Ha! More like opening the gates of CSS hell.

I was just trying to get around my site without typing in URLs like it’s the 1990s, but suddenly I’m deep in a rabbit hole of broken links, unstyled elements, and a navbar that decided it wanted to live its best invisible life.

“I should’ve stuck to the database,” I muttered to myself, watching Bootstrap and Django argue like an old married couple. Who needs TV drama when you have a project like this?

Scene 4: Surrender and Snacks

After hours of this madness, I’m calling it a night.

I’m not giving up—I’m just strategically retreating. Tomorrow is another day, and if Bootstrap thinks it’s won, it’s got another think coming. But for now? It’s time to swap the keyboard for a cup of tea and maybe some cookies.

Fight code with carbs, as they say. (No one says that, but they should.)

Epilogue: The Calm Before the Code

So, dear readers, let this be a lesson: Bootstrap isn’t always your friend. Sometimes, it’s that well-meaning but chaotic relative who rearranges your living room and leaves you wondering where the coffee table went.

Until next time, I’m signing off with a vow: tomorrow, the database will rise again, and this Bootstrap beast will be tamed. Or at the very least, I’ll find a new way to accidentally break my project. 😉

title: Project Submitted: I Wasn't Ready, But Here We Are
author: ljtalks
content:
So, the project is in. Submitted. And guess what? I wasn't ready. Not even close. I was implicitly advised not to look back. Just move on, they said. What’s done is done, they said.

But, you know me—of course, I looked back.

I was reflecting on the final rule of Code Club: delete all commented-out code. Clean is king, right? No rogue lines, no unnecessary clutter. Cool, I can handle that. But then it hit me like a rogue semicolon—wait… did I miss something? I wouldn’t have forgotten that. Right? Who even puts emojis in their comments? 👀

And yet… it kept nagging at me, buzzing around my brain like a bug in an endless loop. Did I, in a moment of pure post-debugging delirium, actually leave a crying-laugh emoji in my code? 😂

I woke up with one of those massive “HUUUH” gasps. The kind where your whole body decides it’s time to panic before you’ve even opened your eyes.

Did I seriously leave an emoji in my code? 🙈

I mean, if I failed because of a rogue emoji, that’s got to be some kind of unique achievement, right? How many Code Institute students can say that was their downfall?

But looking back, it’s not just about an emoji (though I’ll be looking for it—trust me). What I really found was a reminder of how deep this journey took me. I gave everything I had to this course. Blood, sweat, tears, and possibly a few giggles at inappropriate times. And in return? Well, it gave me stuff in absolute spades. Lessons, growth, headaches—yes—but also victories, big and small. And hopefully, my kids will see the benefit of it all when they realize I’ve been steering this ship like a slightly unhinged pirate, but a pirate with intent.

Sure, there’s always a little threat of doom on the horizon, but you know what? I don’t believe in that anymore. I don’t have room for wolves peeking around doors. Desperate people do desperate things—that's something I heard right before I started this course. It hit home then, but now? Nah. No more.

This opportunity didn’t find me because I was desperate. It found me because I was curious. Could I have paid someone to build me a blog? Sure. But where’s the fun in that? I would’ve torn it apart until I understood it better than they did anyway. 😂

I’ll always be grateful to Code Institute (and Facebook ads) for finding me and throwing me into this wild world of coding. I know things are going to be okay. One of my excellent tutors summed it up perfectly: “You’re literally insane. What you’ve achieved is utterly bonkers.” Okay, fine, that’s not exactly what he said, but he’s definitely said stuff like that enough times that I’m confident he meant it.

For those of us who’ve made it this far, we’re legends. We gave it everything we had, and we had the most insane support along the way—people who kept our spirits up while making sure we had no illusions about what we’d signed up for. No pedestals, but wowzers—I needed this.

I know things will never be the same again.

And I’m still looking for that emoji. Maybe it’ll give the assessor a giggle. Honestly, I know I probably didn’t take the docs seriously enough. I know I know I know. And that’s okay. Because an easy win wouldn’t have led me here tonight, celebrating this epic fail in the way I’ve learned to over the last few months.

When people talk about epic fails, I don’t think they fully appreciate how epic failure can actually be. I do now.

And guess what? I’m almost ready for my comeback. I’m done hiding. I know I can help others—even if they just see me and think, “Wow, she literally wouldn’t look up or speak last time I saw her.” I’m here to show people there are options. Possibilities. We all have something inside us, something full of value, just waiting to be shared.

Recently, I had a revelation about sharing. Keeping your value hidden? That’s selfish. We all have a gift. Find out what it is and share it with the world. That’s what I’m doing now—holding the faith, buckling down hard, because this just has to work. No other option.

title: Why I’m Loving the Idea of ‘Starting Simple’—And How That’s Changing Everything
author: ljtalks
content:
If there’s one thing I’ve learned over this crazy journey, it’s the importance of starting simple. Seriously, keep it small, keep it functional, and just get it out there. I spent way too much time on my final project with a million ideas swirling around my head—classic case of scope creep. It wasn’t until I wrapped it up (emoji in the code and all, oops!) that I realized something huge: the value of MVPs.

That’s exactly how I approached my YouTube API app this weekend. Was it perfect? Nope. Did it do the job? Heck yes! And now I’ve got a working tool that solves a real problem, even if it did break the API. 😂

This approach is a game-changer. Don’t get stuck trying to build the perfect solution right away. Test something, see what works, then add the next piece of the puzzle. Rinse and repeat.

LJ Reach, the app I mentioned in my last post, is the best example of this. Instead of trying to create a fully-fledged beast from the start, I’m taking it step by step—getting the basics working first, then adding what’s needed as we go. The same way I learned to build websites, code apps, and solve problems: one step at a time.

It’s also about listening—paying attention to what works and what doesn’t. That’s why getting feedback early on is so important. My vision for LJ Reach is big, but I don’t want to assume I know everything about what’s needed. That’s where people like Peter (or whoever steps up!) come in. Real feedback from real people using the app is what’s going to help shape it into something incredible.

So, to all my fellow builders, creators, and curious souls—start small. Start simple. And keep moving. You’ll be amazed at how quickly those small steps turn into massive leaps forward.

Stay tuned. The fun is just beginning. 🚀

title: The Art of Debugging: A Love-Hate Relationship
author: ljtalks
content:
Ask any developer about their love-hate relationship with debugging, and you’ll get a knowing smile. Today was one of those days—full of errors, fixes, and breakthroughs, each more surprising than the last.

We started the day battling dependency updates and version mismatches—nothing says "good morning" like a GitHub security alert from Dependabot. The classic “should I upgrade this package?” dilemma hit hard when the Gunicorn issue arose. Should we move from version 20.1.0 to 23, knowing it would patch a vulnerability, but potentially introduce new problems? Every decision is a balancing act between security and stability.

From there, it was onto requests, another culprit flagged by security tools. This time, it was about verifying certificates in requests.Session. The logs kept reminding us about issues we hadn’t anticipated, with vulnerabilities lurking in seemingly innocent details like verify=False. It wasn’t long before we were combing through the code for any trace of this setting, relieved when it turned out to be absent.

Then came the migration checks. After adding new models and fields in Gitpod, running migrations in a local environment always feels straightforward. But pushing them live, to Heroku, and suddenly seeing a 500 error instead of the homepage? That’s when the real panic starts.

Even after realizing that migrations were set up correctly, debugging the mysterious Heroku error felt like a marathon in itself. We swapped out configurations, poked around the logs, and eventually realized the culprit might not be in the code at all. Was it the static files not updating correctly? Was it something in the collectstatic process? It turned out to be a mix of small issues that together formed the infamous “500 Server Error.”

Breakthroughs Always Follow the Struggle

While it was frustrating in the moment, there’s a certain satisfaction in pushing through and figuring out why something wasn’t working. Whether it’s updating configuration files, running collectstatic, or just cleaning up after multiple failed deploys—every fix is a step closer to the final breakthrough.

That said, we’ve all hit that point where stepping away is the best option. You know it’s bad when you start questioning everything, from the code to why Da Vinci (who was a polymath, by the way—not the guy who cut his ear off, that was Van Gogh) spent so much time obsessing over his craft. But here’s the twist: that frustration is often a sign you’re on the verge of something big. You might just need to give your brain a break before that “aha” moment hits.

So after hours of pushing, pulling, testing, and tweaking, we’re putting a hold on the battle for the night. Tomorrow, it’ll feel clearer—and we’ll be ready to jump back in, fresh and ready to tackle those 500 errors with a clear head.

In the meantime, we’ve learned a few key lessons:

  1. Polymaths and Developers Share the Same DNA: We’re not just programmers; we’re problem-solvers, security experts, and sometimes, even server admins. The more hats we wear, the more adept we become at navigating these complex landscapes.

  2. Security Is No Joke: Today’s GitHub and Heroku issues reminded us that vulnerabilities can pop up anywhere—whether in outdated packages or overlooked settings. Keep your stack updated, and never ignore those pesky security alerts.

  3. Know When to Walk Away: Debugging is like trying to solve a puzzle while blindfolded. Sometimes, you just need to step away and come back with fresh eyes.

For now, we’ll let the errors rest and come back stronger tomorrow. As every dev knows, the next breakthrough is just around the corner—especially after a long day of trials and errors.

title: Day of the ERD Drama, Plot Twists, and ‘Let’s Keep It Simple’ Realizations
author: ljtalks
content:
Well, folks, buckle up because today has been an absolute whirlwind in the land of “Let’s Build an MVP and Hope for the Best.” 🎢

First things first, I came into today ready to tackle my project planning like a boss. I had my coffee in hand, a decent night's sleep (more or less), and a head full of ideas. I was ready to nail down this whole project like it was no big deal.

Step 1: The ER Diagram. You know, that thing that looks all neat and tidy on paper but secretly lurks around corners waiting to smack you in the face with a “Did you really think this was gonna be easy?”

So there I am, mapping out Users and Bookings with all the confidence of a professional diagrammer (yep, I made up that word). “Users will book services, and they’ll also buy digital products,” I thought, “Easy peasy.” Except, plot twist — in walks the realization that webinars, mentoring, PDFs, and online courses might just belong to totally different worlds. Like, wait a minute — are webinars services or products? Do mentoring sessions need their own booking system? Should I just throw the whole thing out the window and start again? 🤔

Step 2: Panic. For a brief moment, I questioned my entire existence. But then I had an epiphany: KEEP IT SIMPLE. Yes, simplicity — the holy grail of getting an MVP done without losing your mind. So, after a quick chat with my tutor (who, might I add, probably heard the panic in my voice from a mile away), we agreed: we’re keeping Products for now and saving the complicated service stuff for later. Future me can deal with that mess.

Step 3: Blogging about it. Then it hit me. This whole process of planning, scrapping ideas, re-planning, and talking myself down from the ledge is exactly the kind of thing people love to read about. Why not blog about every twist and turn? After all, if I’m learning at breakneck speed, surely others will find it useful. Plus, it’ll be fun to look back on all the chaos, right?

Moral of the story: Today’s big win was realizing that less is more (at least for now), and I’m just going to focus on making things functional. No more chasing my own tail trying to figure out if my webinars belong in the service app or the product app. They can stay in the product app, and I’ll sleep soundly tonight knowing I haven’t created a booking system that looks like spaghetti.

So here we are, at the end of the day. The ER Diagram has been updated, my sanity has been restored (mostly), and I’ve learned that keeping it simple might just be the key to success. Who knew?

Stay tuned for tomorrow’s episode of “What Could Possibly Go Wrong?” 😉

title: The Curious Case of the Cat? the ERD, and the Mysterious Many-to-One
author: ljtalks
content:
Project.Blog Day2 

I started today with a mission. A mission I thought I was prepared for. I had my black coffee in one hand and a freshly sharpened mind in the other. It was going to be a productive day.

And then I saw the todo list… it was Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD) Day… 

This wasn't just any ERD. Oh no, this was an ERD of epic proportions, an ERD that would rival any cryptic crossword puzzle. One minute I was confidently dragging lines between my User model and Blog post, and the next... those lines seemed to have minds of their own, darting across the screen like untrained puppies chasing squirrels.

Many-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many — did I even know what these terms meant anymore? For a while, it seemed like all those "ones" and "manys" were conspiring against me. And let’s not even talk about how many times I had to undo my perfectly placed boxes just because a line decided it didn’t like where it was heading!

But then, just as I was about to throw in the towel (or perhaps my laptop), the pieces started to click. It wasn’t just about drawing lines and placing boxes — no, this was about understanding relationships. It was about realizing that a User could comment on multiple Blogs but each Comment only had one User. It was about knowing that each Product was part of a bigger system, interacting with Purchases, Comments, and Blogs.

Eraser.io may have been my battleground today, but it taught me a lesson: sometimes, it’s not the tools that make or break a diagram — it’s the clarity of the relationships you're trying to define. I learned how critical it was to understand those connections deeply. Because once I did, the lines between the boxes stopped running wild and started falling into place.

And let's not forget the comedic moments: that time when half the lines overlapped and I genuinely thought I’d invented a new form of abstract art... or when I learned what a clob was (no, not the sound you make when you drop your phone on the floor).

So, while the day may have started with confusion, it ended with a masterpiece of clarity (and a LOT of undo’s). Now I have an ERD that makes sense, and I can proudly say — the one-to-many's and many-to-one's no longer terrify me.

Lesson of the day: The only way to truly master an ERD is to let it be messy for a while. Let the lines run amok, let the boxes overlap — because in the end, it’s all part of the process. Eventually, everything will fall into place.

Stay tuned for tomorrow's blog post, where I’ll inevitably find myself in yet another database dilemma. Who knows, maybe next time I’ll decide to get creative with… many-to-many relationships? 😬

Until then, my ERD and I are signing off, one (relationship) at a time!
